title: Torque exerted on an unwrapping roll

content.question:

The diagram shows a long, thin sheet of flexible metal that is wrapped many times around a plastic roller with radius <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Initially a small part of the metal sheet hangs vertically from the edge of the roller as shown in the above figures and the roller is held stationary. Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></math> is marked on the side of the roller a distance <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the center of the roller. (b) Explain how the student could use the function for <math alttext="theta of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the value of the angular speed <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> after the roller has undergone a single rotation.

(c) In what direction is the acceleration of point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></math> at the instant the roller has completed a single rotation? Justify your answer.

The function <math alttext="theta of t equals, A t to the fourth power, plus B t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> indicates that the net torque acting on the roller is increasing with time.
(d) Explain how the function shows that the net torque exerted on the roller is increasing with time.
(e) Give a physical reason why the net torque exerted on the roller increases with time.

After all the metal has unwound from the roller, the student measures the radius <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the roller to be <math alttext="10 centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="15 radians per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mstyle><mrow><mtext>rad/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> respectively. Observed from the side, the roller rotates counterclockwise, as shown. A piece of clay of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> strikes the very bottom edge of the roller with a horizontal velocity <math alttext="v equals 3.0 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . The clay sticks to and rotates with the roller. The clay-roller system then rotates with a final angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(f) Is <math alttext="omega sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

The clay completes half of a single rotation and then loses contact with the roller when it is directly over the center of the roller. The clay travels forward and falls towards the ground and the roller continues to rotate at angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> .

(g) Is <math alttext="omega sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="omega sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.
